item.title: Headhunters for headteachers: schools pay firms up to £50,000 to find leaders
item.trailText: Some schools are paying huge sums to recruitment consultants because there are so few candidates willing to put their neck on the line in the top job
item.standFirst: Some schools are paying huge sums to recruitment consultants because there are so few candidates willing to put their neck on the line in the top job
item.body:
When Ruth Whymark, headteacher of Cranmer primary school in Mitcham, Surrey, decided to move on, she was well aware that her school might find replacing her a challenge: a shortage of headteachers is making recruitment an uphill struggle for many schools. So as well as advertising the post in the press, Cranmer – a three-form entry school with a “good” Ofsted rating – produced its own advertising.

“The YouTube clip was my idea,” says Whymark. “I knew we had to engage with different media to get our advert out there, so I asked our ICT lead if he could make it, and then we tweeted it to everyone.”

Featuring the catchy Best Day of My Life track by American Authors, the three-minute video intersperses shots of children playing, in class, and performing in a nativity play, with short interviews. Staff, governors and pupils explain what they love about their school and describe the qualities they’re looking for in a head.

“The headteacher we’ve recruited had been approached about other jobs in the past but hadn’t bothered to apply,” says Whymark. It was the YouTube film that inspired her to find out more about Cranmer and apply.

But even with a feelgood video shared widely on social media, and an advert placed in time for the Christmas holidays, Whymark says Cranmer still struggled to recruit. Despite offering a higher salary, there were fewer applicants than expected. “People are very hesitant about moving,” says Whymark. “Being a head is like being a football manager at the moment. One bad season and you’re out.” For Whymark, it’s a problem she will no longer be facing. Her next job is a three-year contract as head of an international junior school in China.

The shortage of headteachers and lack of support for governing bodies are pushing schools towards using expensive headhunters, say education and industry experts. “We’re hearing about a growing number of schools having to advertise leadership positions two or three times to secure a single appointable candidate,” says David Simmonds, chairman of the Local Government Association’s children and young people board. The LGA is investigating the scale of the problem and says action must be taken now to avert a crisis.

“It’s becoming essential to use a recruitment consultancy,” says Simmonds, who is concerned about the cost of this to schools. Fees for a full headhunting service range from £15,000 to £50,000, says David Evans, a former teacher and now director of education services at Synarbor Education, the UK’s second largest specialist education recruitment firm. Others in the industry suggest typical fees of about £20,000 for a secondary school executive search and £15,000 for primaries.

Cheaper packages, which offer a level of support previously provided by local authorities, include help with advertising, shortlisting, background checks, selection on the day and pay negotiation. They start at a few thousand pounds rising to about £18,000.

Being a head is like being a football manager at the moment. One bad season and you’re out

Ruth Whymark

Evans says Synarbor gets two or three requests a week from schools for recruitment services but turns most down. He will work only with governing bodies willing to pay for the full headhunting service, which many deem too expensive. “There’s a massive growing shortage of heads with the retirement boom and not enough talent coming through,” he says. Deputy heads on high salaries have little incentive to progress, says Evans, and many good leaders are simply not interested in moving.

Evans argues that using headhunters from the outset is the best plan. He says that if schools approach an agency having advertised unsuccessfully, it is harder to recruit, so they’re likely to be charged higher fees.

But employing consultants after failing to find a head is a common pattern. Schools that do not appoint on their first or second attempt often feel their only option is to bring in a recruitment firm.

For one “outstanding” infant school in Buckinghamshire, the process took more than a year. Its first advert, in February 2014, generated just two candidates, both unsuitable. The second produced no applications at all.

“At that point we decided we needed some help and hired recruitment consultants,” says the chair of governors, who asked for the school not to be named. “But we noticed that we got a lot of generic responses through them, rather than people specifically interested in our school. It may have been that they had candidates on their books that were just sending out application after application.”

In the end, after a fourth round of advertising, a local candidate was appointed. She had not been alerted to the position by the recruiters, who emailed prospective heads, but had applied for the job directly. By this point the school had spent £7,000 on recruitment fees and a further £3,600 on advertising.

“With hindsight, the recruitment firm didn’t help much at all,” says the chair. The governing body rewrote the job description and advert, with minimal input from the consultant. In fact, the chair thinks the recruitment firm may have had a detrimental effect on the process by encouraging unsuitable candidates to apply.

Despite their reservations, the governors felt the risk of proceeding without consultants was too great. “We were worried we’d have been seen as failing the school if we continued on our own after two failed attempts to recruit.”

The pressure to appoint the right candidate from a shrinking field of applicants is clearly increasing business opportunities for recruiters. At Judicium Education, a private company that offers schools a variety of support services, leadership recruitment is its fastest area of growth. Director Alex Metha says business has already doubled this year compared with the whole of 2014, and that the shortage of headteachers is affecting all sectors.

At Cranmer school, Whymark says: “It’s such a difficult market out there. But I don’t think a lot of headteachers and governing bodies realise they need to do more than just put an advert in. There’s no sense of urgency.”

John Howson, a former government adviser on teacher recruitment, says an increase in demand for secondary school leaders, exacerbated by the creation of new schools, is a significant factor. In primary schools, increased workload and pressure from Ofsted mean fewer senior staff apply for headteacher positions.

“In the old days, local authorities were around to hold your hand,” says Howson. “Now, if you’re in an academy you’re on your own. Unless you happen to have someone on the governing body who understands how to recruit, it’s a big risk. Most governors only recruit a head once.”

He says about 75% of headship vacancies posted at the right time of the year are still filled through advertising. But, he says, it is inevitable that recruitment agencies will play a larger role, as the lack of support for governing bodies means they feel it makes sense for them to pay for services. Howson has set up a website, TeachVac, to try to reduce schools’ recruitment costs by offering free advertising. He hopes the money schools save can be used to improve teaching and learning.

But if advertising alone cannot secure a new head, how can schools hope to reduce costs in this area? Ian Bauckham, a headteacher in Kent and former president of the Association of School and College Leaders, offers a bleak analysis. “The days of putting an advert out and getting 20 applicants are long gone,” he says. “Everything is moving towards a headhunting model.”

The ASCL has a leadership appointment service offering support to governing bodies appointing a headteacher. It is now considering moving towards a headhunting model itself.

As Bauckham cautions, though, however much schools are prepared to pay for headhunting, the problem of filling vacancies will persist until more fundamental issues about the shortage of candidates are addressed. And until that happens, it looks like business will boom for recruiters.

item.trailText: Scores of Palestinians, including many women, have been flocking to Wadi Climbing, a pioneering school founded by American students
item.standFirst: Scores of Palestinians, including many women, have been flocking to Wadi Climbing, a pioneering school founded by American students
item.body:
Rubaa Bledi, 16, is being lowered to the ground having completed her first rock climb. “I was trembling!” the Palestinian schoolgirl says breathlessly as she rests her head on her knees.

Her face is hidden for a moment by her headscarf and helmet. “I wanted to know if I could do something risky,” she says when she recovers. “I wanted to know if I was up to the adventure.”

It is Saturday and we’re on the cliffs of Ein Qiniya, a band of bulging orange limestone that fringes a valley full of thorn scrub and olive groves outside Ramallah, the de facto Palestinian capital of the West Bank.

Rubaa is one of a group of about 20 Palestinians, including students and telecoms workers, attending a course run by Wadi Climbing, an initiative set up by two young Americans.

The participants have travelled from across the West Bank – from nearby Ramallah, Jenin and Nablus – to attempt a sport in its infancy in the occupied territories.

Rubaa says her parents were anxious about her new pastime. “My father didn’t want me to come,” she says. “He told me: ‘Next year you’ll be in the 12th grade. It’s too important to be injured.’” But Rubaa was determined. “I kept asking and told him: ‘Daddy, I really want to come.’”

In almost a year, about 500 people have attended Wadi Climbing’s courses, most Palestinian and 40% of them women.

“Summer” Rushdi is older and more experienced. “A friend of my sister posted a link on Facebook and I knew I wanted to try it. And this is something people do in the rest of the world. That’s another reason why it is inviting,” she says.

“And we are so involved with the reality of the [Israeli] occupation. It is all about the struggle. And it becomes part of our mentality. It is good to do what other people are doing elsewhere in the world, where people have the time and the opportunity to do different activities. That is why it is so good that this is also available to us now.”

Most of those on the Wadi Climbing course are well-educated and speak fluent English. But later in the afternoon three Bedouin youths arrive. They are not part of the course, which costs about £12 for a weekend of instruction, but borrow harnesses and shoes and get on to the rock.

One of the two founders of Wadi Climbing, Will Harris, explains its genesis. “My partner Tim and I were living in Amman in Jordan and studying Arabic.” He says during a visit to the occupied Palestinian territories the pair were struck by the lack of recreational facilities.

Much of the equipment provided on the course, including climbing shoes and harnesses, was sourced from the lost-and-found cupboards at two climbing walls in Colorado, where Wadi Climbing’s founders went to college.

“We came last July – we had done a feasibility trip last January. People were overwhelmingly positive in their response so we moved here.” Wadi Climbing has developed two cliffs close to Ramallah and plans for the city’s first climbing wall are in the pipeline.

The reality of the occupation is difficult to avoid, even in this quiet and pretty corner of the West Bank. In the distance a settlement and Israeli military tower are visible – both factors have limited the development of climbing.

“Most of climbing on the West Bank has been developed by Israeli climbers,” says Harris. “When we first came we only met one Palestinian climber. In comparison with the Palestinian territories, Israeli climbing is very active. The Israeli climbing club alone has some 3000 members. Most of that climbing on the West Bank is in Area C [ie under Israeli security control and administration]. And it is close to settlements.

“If you go to Ein Fara [a major climbing area for Israelis in an Israeli-controlled nature reserve in the occupied Palestinian territories between Jerusalem and Jericho] you either have to go through the neighbouring settlement and pay or you have a 40-minute walk.

Rock climbing is something people do in the rest of the world. That’s another reason why it is inviting

Summer Rushdi

“We recently took our first group of Palestinians into that Wadi by the walk-in access Palestinians are allowed to use. While we were on the trail two [Israeli] security guards approached us to ask where we had come from. We told them we were going to climb and they said it was OK.”

They have received support from high-profile climbers, including Nina Caprez, from Switzerland, who was visiting on a sponsored trip and had inquired about the possibility of climbing in the Palestinian territories.

Harris tells the story of the young Bedouins who come to climb when he is running his courses. “Friday is their only day off and all they want to do is climb. Some of them work in construction in Rehan [a new Palestinian town being built on the ridge opposite the Ein Qiniya cliffs],” he says. “They can look over towards the cliff and if they see us they run across the valley to come climbing. These guys will be the future of Palestinian climbing.”

Fifteen minutes after her first climb Rubaa is ready to try another. She asks if she can use the Guardian’s rope. This time she runs up the climb. When she returns to the ground all nervousness has gone. “This is so much fun,” she says. “I want to come again.”
